docs.lead_paragraph: When George E. Pataki campaigned for governor in 1994, he vowed to do what the incumbent, Mario M. Cuomo, had proposed but could never fully deliver: to cut taxes across the board in New York, beginning with the state's notoriously high income tax. Shortly after taking office, Mr. Pataki pushed through an average 20 percent reduction in the state's income tax rate, with the top rate dropping to 6.85 percent from 7.875 percent, bringing it to the lowest level in New York since 1953 and removing half a million low-income workers from the tax rolls.

headline.main: Budget Growth Clouds Pataki Legacy of Tax Cuts

docs.abstract: Second article in series 10 Years Later examines aspects of state government in time since Gov George E Pataki took office; Pataki in 1995 pushed through average 20 percent reduction in state's income tax rate, bringing it to lowest level in New York since 1953 and removing 500,000 low-income workers from tax rolls; different fiscal reality has settled in after budget austerity of Pataki's first term; state spending has regularly outpaced inflation, with size of New York State's budget rising from $77.8 billion in 1997-98 fiscal year to $96 billion in 2003-4 fiscal year; analysts warn that such unchecked spending could help undo one of Pataki's most significant achievements as governor; New York's state and local tax burden, driven especially by high local taxes, is among highest in nation, even with governor's tax cuts; graphs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Fiscal analysts warn that unchecked spending could help undo Gov. George E. Pataki's early tax cuts in New York.

byline.original: By AL BAKER and JO CRAVEN McGINTY

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge yesterday reduced the sentence of a prominent Manhattan gynecologist who is in prison for insurance fraud. The gynecologist, Niels H. Lauersen, 68, submitted false bills worth $3.2 million to pay for fertility surgery for his patients that insurance companies did not cover. He will serve 5 years and 10 months instead of the original sentence of 7 years and 3 months he received in October 2001. In lowering the term , the judge, William H. Pauley III, cited Mr. Lauersen's age and the fact that he will likely be deported to his native Denmark after he is released. He has already served four years.
docs.abstract: Federal Judge William H Pauley III reduces sentence of prominent Manhattan gynecologist Niels H Lauersen, who is in prison for insurance fraud; cites Lauersen's age and fact that he will likely be deported after he is released; he will serve 5 years and 10 months instead of original 7 years and 3 months; has already served four years (M)
docs.snippet: A federal judge yesterday reduced the sentence of a prominent Manhattan gynecologist who is in prison for insurance fraud.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an implicit but devastating account of the havoc AIDS is causing here, South Africa's government reported Friday that annual deaths increased 57 percent from 1997 to 2003, with common AIDS-related diseases like tuberculosis and pneumonia fueling much of the rise. The increase in mortality spanned all age groups, but was most pronounced among those between ages 15 and 49, where deaths more than doubled. Working-age adults are more sexually active than the rest of the population, and the opportunity for transmitting H.I.V. is greatest among members of this group.

headline.main: AIDS-Linked Death Data Stir Political Storm in South Africa

docs.abstract: South Africa reports that annual deaths increased 57 percent from 1997 to 2003, with AIDS-related diseases like turberculosis and pneumonia fueling much of rise; increase spanned all age groups, but was most pronounced among those between ages 15 and 49, where deaths more than doubled; critics assail Pres Thabo Mbeki's government for playing down AIDS crisis (M)
docs.snippet: Officials said that annual deaths increased 57 percent from 1997 to 2003, with AIDS-related diseases fueling much of the rise.

docs.lead_paragraph: The 45-day work stoppage at the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, an increasingly bitter dispute at a place known for its friendliness, has begun to take a heavy toll. Players, some with heavy loan payments for instruments, are feeling the financial bite. They have taken on new students. A violist went off to work as a ski technician in Aspen. A violinist has picked up more mariachi gigs. One couple who both play in the orchestra, Heidi and Erik Harris, have used the opportunity to expand their cosmetics business. A dozen members have been substituting in other orchestras around the country, an ominous sign for those who fear a talent drain.

headline.main: The Silence In St. Louis Is Starting To Hurt

docs.abstract: Work stoppage at St Louis Symphony Orchestra, which began on January 3, is taking heavy financial toll on players, who are taking on side jobs and new students or expanding businesses; orchestra says it has lost more than $700,000 in revenue; both sides are slated to meet with federal mediator; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The 45-day work stoppage at the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, an increasingly bitter dispute at a place known for its friendliness, has begun to take a heavy toll.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress, governors and the secretary of health and human services began negotiations Wednesday on the future of Medicaid, with a view to making fundamental changes in the program to control its costs. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa and the chairman of the Finance Committee, said Congress and the governors were trying to develop a relationship like the one that produced sweeping changes in federal welfare law in 1996.

headline.main: Governors in Capital to Talk About Medicaid

docs.abstract: Negotiations among Congress, governors and Health and Human Services Sec Michael O Leavitt on future of Medicaid begin, with view to making fundamental changes in program to control costs; spending has increased 63 percent in five years and federal and state outlays now total more than $300 billion yearly; Leavitt says Pres Bush wants to give states more freedom to decide who gets what benefits, while cracking down on abusive practices by states to maximize what they receive; governors fear Congress will limit Medicaid spending without relieving states of any of their legal or financial obligations; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Congress, governors and the secretary of health and human services began negotiations on the future of Medicaid, hoping to control the program's costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Democrats Getting Lessons in Speaking Their Values'' (Congressional Memo, Feb. 11):
docs.abstract: Letter from Joan Malin (Planned Parenthood of New York City) holds it is troubling to see false dichotomy emerge between those who see abortion and same-sex marriage as divisive 'below the waist' issues and those who see them as fundamental to living in a free and fair society (Feb 11 article)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PLANNED PARENTHOOD OF NEW YORK CITY

docs.lead_paragraph: Humana, a health plan manager, said it expected its profit to rise to 61 cents to 63 cents a share in the first quarter, more than an earlier forecast, as a result of its purchase of CarePlus Health Plans of Florida. The CarePlus acquisition, completed yesterday, added 50,000 customers in three Florida counties who are eligible for benefits under Medicare. Humana estimated that enrollment in its Medicare programs would rise to 470,000 to 485,000 by the end of the year. Humana said revenue for the full year would be about $14.5 billion.

headline.main: HUMANA RAISES PROFIT ESTIMATE FOR FIRST QUARTER

docs.abstract: Humana expects its profit to rise to 61 cents to 63 cents a share in first quarter, more than earlier forecast; says revenue for full year will be about $14.5 billion; estimates its enrollment in its Medicare programs will rise to 470,000 to 485,000 by end of year (S)
docs.snippet: Humana, a health plan manager, said it expected its profit to rise to 61 cents to 63 cents a share in the first quarter, more than an earlier forecast, as a result of its purchase of CarePlus Health Plans of Florida. The CarePlus acquisition,...

docs.lead_paragraph: The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to require defibrillators to be available in thousands of public places, including courthouses, municipal office buildings, ferry terminals, stadiums, nursing homes, large health clubs, and some parks and golf courses. Council Speaker Gifford Miller said that about $1 million would be spent to install the defibrillators in city-owned locations, while owners of other buildings used by the public would be responsible for the cost there. The Council also passed another law yesterday to create a citywide program to allow New Yorkers without medical insurance and others to buy prescription drugs at a discount. Aides to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that he is expected to sign both laws. Winnie Hu (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City To Install Defibrillators

docs.abstract: New York City Council votes unanimously to require defibrillators to be available in thousands of public places, including courthouses, municipal office buildings, stadiums, large health clubs and some parks and golf courses (S)

byline.original: By Winnie Hu (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: Although the two never met, Maxine Watson saved Carol Call's life. In fact, Ms. Watson saved at least two lives and helped heal dozens of other people. She did so in death, having arranged for her organs to be donated to those who needed them most.

headline.main: Linked Forever by the Ultimate Gift; One Woman's Death Provides Life for Another

docs.abstract: Carol Call, patient with emphysema at New York-Presbyterian Hospital, receives life-saving transplant of lungs taken from Maxine Watson after her death from stroke at Bellevue Hospital; case offers rare glimpse into often misunderstood world, where confidentiality agreements usually keep donor families from learning names of those they have saved and keep recipients from learning names of their saviors; 48 hours after receiving her new lungs, Call sends message thanking Watson's family; photos (L)
docs.snippet: After her death, Maxine Watson saved at least two lives, having arranged for her organs to be donated to those who needed them most.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof cites a study of 4,000 North Carolinians in which frequent churchgoers were found to have a 46 percent lower risk of dying in a six-year period than those who attended less often. This statistic is particularly startling in light of the fact that a sizable number of North Carolinians do not have health insurance, and many more are inadequately covered.

headline.main: The Faithful: A Matter of Genes?

docs.abstract: David Fellerath letter questions study cited by Nicholas Kristof in Feb 12 column, suggesting health benefits of attending church
